original.definition: distribute (players or teams) so that outstanding teams or players will not meet in the early rounds

sememes.reasoning: The verb 'seed' describes the act of altering the arrangement or distribution of participants within a competitive structure.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' who intentionally performs the action of distributing or ranking the players or teams.
The 'somebody' (referring to players or teams) whose distribution or arrangement is being changed.

sememes.reasoning: A fundamental characteristic of 'seeding' is its strategic purpose, which is to ensure a balanced competition by preventing top contenders from meeting in early rounds, as stated in the definition.

Evidentiality.reasoning: The act of seeding is a directly observed or implemented organizational process.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, describing an action or process.

Modality.reasoning: The presence of 'Somebody' in the frame indicates that the action is driven by an agent's will and intention.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of seeding itself is a neutral procedural action; its outcomes can be perceived positively or negatively, but the act is neutral.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody seed somebody' explicitly includes a volitional agent, making the action intentional.

Confidence.reasoning: The act of seeding is described as a definite and executed process.

Iterativity.reasoning: Seeding is typically a single, discrete event or process applied to a competition before it begins, not a continuously repeated action.

candidates.description: a festivity in ancient Greece at which competitors contended for prizes (gloss match)
advancing as if in the child's game, by leaping over obstacles or competitors (gloss match)
a light movable barrier that competitors must leap over in certain races (gloss match)
genes that are not competitors at the same locus (gloss match)
an ordered listing of scores or results showing the relative positions of competitors (individuals or teams) in a sporting event (gloss match)
misinformation that is deliberately disseminated in order to influence or confuse rivals (foreign enemies or business competitors etc.) (gloss match)
a race in which competitors must negotiate obstacles (gloss match)
a novelty race in which competitors move potatoes from one place to another one at a time (gloss match)
a novelty race in which competitors jump ahead with their feet confined in a sack (gloss match)
all the competitors in a particular contest or sporting event (gloss match)
one of four competitors remaining in a tournament by elimination (gloss match)
(military) a secret agent hired by a state to obtain information about its enemies or by a business to obtain industrial secrets from competitors (gloss match)
any one of two or more competitors who tie one another (gloss match)
intense competition in which competitors cut retail prices to gain business (gloss match)
a position of superiority over opponents or competitors (gloss match)
(economics) a market in which control over the supply of a commodity is in the hands of a small number of producers and each one can influence prices and affect competitors (gloss match)
an economic condition that results in the elimination of marginally financed participants in an industry (gloss match)
